articles.headline: Mideast Din Drowns Out Palestinians
articles.snippet: With Israel and other world powers focusing on the Arab Spring and the mounting tensions with Iran, the Palestinian issue has effectively been shelved, leaving Palestinian leaders at a loss.
articles.abstract: With Israel and other world powers focusing on the Arab Spring and the mounting tensions with Iran, the Palestinian issue has effectively been shelved, leaving Palestinian leaders at a loss.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — In the 14 months since revolution has spread across the Middle East and tension has soared over Iran’s nuclear program, the Palestinian leadership has found itself orphaned. Politically divided, its peace talks with Israel collapsed and its foreign support waning, the Palestinian Authority is sidelined, confused and worried that its people may return to violence.

articles.headline: Apple Adds Sharper Screen and Speed to New iPad
articles.snippet: The new iPad has a high-definition screen, faster wireless connection and several other refinements for the same price as the old one, $499.
articles.abstract: The new iPad has a high-definition screen, faster wireless connection and several other refinements for the same price as the old one, $499.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple updated the iPad on Wednesday with a high-definition screen, a faster wireless connection and several other refinements, all packaged in a device without any major design changes.

articles.headline: Exercising an Aging Brain
articles.snippet: Some people may be thinking of second careers, while others hope to forestall the mental declines of age.
articles.abstract: Some people may be thinking of second careers, while others hope to forestall the mental declines of age.
articles.lead_paragraph: MORE and more retired people are heading back to the nearest classroom — as students and, in some cases, teachers — and they are finding out that school can be lovelier the second time around. Some may be thinking of second careers, but most just want to keep their minds stimulated, learn something new or catch up with a subject they were always curious about but never had time for.

articles.headline: Aging Stars in a New Role: TV Pitchman
articles.snippet: There is a growing demand for no-longer-ready-for-prime-time celebrities willing to vouch for products in ads often shown during reruns of movies and TV shows they made during their salad days.
articles.abstract: There is a growing demand for no-longer-ready-for-prime-time celebrities willing to vouch for products in ads often shown during reruns of movies and TV shows they made during their salad days.
articles.lead_paragraph: THEY will always be defined by the roles they played. Robert Wagner is the suave star of “It Takes a Thief” and “Hart to Hart.” Patrick Duffy will be forever be J. R.’s younger brother on “Dallas” (except to those who remember him as the piscine star of “Man From Atlantis”).

articles.headline: After the Storm, the Little Nest Eggs That Couldn’t
articles.snippet: The financial crisis of 2008 and the uncertainty that continues today have made many people radically alter their plans, but some basic principles still apply.
articles.abstract: The financial crisis of 2008 and the uncertainty that continues today have made many people radically alter their plans, but some basic principles still apply.
articles.lead_paragraph: A DECADE ago, Jonnie Worth had her eyes on retiring at age 62. Year after year, she funneled money into her 401(k), first when she worked as an event planner and later when she worked in the private banking department at JPMorgan Chase. But the financial crisis of 2008 swamped Ms. Worth. “Like everyone else, I watched my retirement savings plummet,” she said. “I lost a big percentage of my investments.”

articles.headline: A Clutch of Cunning Inventions
articles.snippet: Six technology products that won’t rock the world but are worth noting, including a jacket with 20 gadget-holding pockets and a voice-activated alarm clock.
articles.abstract: Six technology products that won’t rock the world but are worth noting, including a jacket with 20 gadget-holding pockets and a voice-activated alarm clock.
articles.lead_paragraph: Every now and then, a technology product comes along that’s so profoundly brilliant, the world changes forever.

articles.headline: Cost of Gene Sequencing Falls, Raising Hopes for Medical Advances
articles.snippet: Firms are racing to cut the cost of sequencing the human genome, which will yield new approaches for treating cancers and other serious diseases, biologists say.
articles.abstract: Firms are racing to cut the cost of sequencing the human genome, which will yield new approaches for treating cancers and other serious diseases, biologists say.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — In Silicon Valley, the line between computing and biology has begun to blur in a way that could have enormous consequences for human longevity.

articles.headline: Intractable Afghan Graft Hampering U.S. Strategy
articles.snippet: Despite years of urging and oversight by American advisers, President Hamid Karzai’s government has yet to prosecute a high-level corruption case in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: Despite years of urging and oversight by American advisers, President Hamid Karzai’s government has yet to prosecute a high-level corruption case in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — For the past few months, possibly the most intriguing poker game in Kabul has been taking place in the sprawling pink sitting room of the man at the center of one of the most public corruption scandals in the world, the near collapse of Kabul Bank.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: Women in Texas Losing Options for Health Care in Abortion Fight
articles.snippet: The cuts, which have left many low-income women with inconvenient or costly options for treatment, grew out of a plan to eliminate state support for Planned Parenthood.
articles.abstract: The cuts, which have left many low-income women with inconvenient or costly options for treatment, grew out of a plan to eliminate state support for Planned Parenthood.
articles.lead_paragraph: Leticia Parra, a mother of five scraping by on income from her husband’s sporadic construction jobs, relied on the Planned Parenthood clinic in San Carlos, an impoverished town in South Texas, for breast cancer screenings, free birth control pills and pap smears for cervical cancer.
articles.byline: By Pam Belluck and Emily Ramshaw

articles.headline: In Bonds, Bull Market for Firms
articles.snippet: Money is cheap for companies with good credit, and they are piling into the corporate bond market. But what is good for borrowers may not be so good for lenders.
articles.abstract: Money is cheap for companies with good credit, and they are piling into the corporate bond market. But what is good for borrowers may not be so good for lenders.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Advance Auto Parts executives said the timing was right.

articles.headline: At Airline, a Pensions Compromise
articles.snippet: AMR, American Airlines’ parent, said it would freeze pension plans for everyone except its pilots.
articles.abstract: AMR, American Airlines’ parent, said it would freeze pension plans for everyone except its pilots.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMR Corporation, the parent of bankrupt American Airlines, pulled back on Wednesday from its previous threats to terminate all employee pension plans.

articles.headline: Romney Lags in Small Donors as Big Givers Hit Limits
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney’s high-dollar donors, lavish fund-raising events and personal wealth fuel perceptions that he is favored more by his party’s elite than by its conservative base.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney’s high-dollar donors, lavish fund-raising events and personal wealth fuel perceptions that he is favored more by his party’s elite than by its conservative base.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney has more delegates, more money and more endorsements than any of his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination. But with a split verdict on Super Tuesday and no quick finish in sight, he is struggling to match the enthusiasm and money his rivals have harnessed from grass-roots donors.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Obama Mines for Voters With High-Tech Tools
articles.snippet: The heart of the president’s re-election campaign can be found in a Chicago office complex, where political strategists, data analysts and other workers search online to reconnect with supporters from four years ago.
articles.abstract: The heart of the president’s re-election campaign can be found in a Chicago office complex, where political strategists, data analysts and other workers search online to reconnect with supporters from four years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — With a “chief scientist” specializing in consumer behavior, an “analytics department” monitoring voter trends, and a squad of dozens huddled at computer screens editing video or writing code, the sprawling office complex inside One Prudential Plaza looks like a corporate research and development lab — Ping-Pong table and all.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Greek Swap of Its Debt Appears to Be Secure
articles.snippet: Greece appeared to be closer to receiving bailout funds from Europe and the International Monetary Fund after its debt swap was approved by more than a majority of its lenders.
articles.abstract: Greece appeared to be closer to receiving bailout funds from Europe and the International Monetary Fund after its debt swap was approved by more than a majority of its lenders.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Greece appeared to have clinched a landmark debt restructuring deal with its private sector lenders late Thursday. The deal would clear the way for the release of bailout funds from Europe and the International Monetary Fund that would save the country from default.

articles.headline: Japan Looks Beyond Its Borders for Investors
articles.snippet: Japan, once a manufacturing powerhouse known for exports, is finding it must do what it has long resisted: welcome foreign manufacturers.
articles.abstract: Japan, once a manufacturing powerhouse known for exports, is finding it must do what it has long resisted: welcome foreign manufacturers.
articles.lead_paragraph: AIZU-WAKAMATSU, Japan — Mayor Shohei Muroi knows it is a tough sell to get new companies to invest in this struggling industrial city just 60 miles from Japan’s most notorious nuclear plant.
